ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to appreciate less mainstream films and think about the ways that a story can be told. Also learned about a lot of interesting Black filmmakers that Id never heard of. It was definitely a shift from Hollywood which was welcomed.
Learned a lot in a short amount of time. The material was really interesting, and it was so special attending screenings and engaging with the films in class discussions.
Through a varied and well-curated curriculum of films, I was able to develop my knowledge of film history, theory, and analysis.

I learned a lot about the film industry, Black independent films, and Black filmmakers. There was more focus on directors than I had expected which was great. I also definitely think that my writing evolved throughout the course of the semester, although at times it was very difficult to work with the blogposts' open promote. It really forces you to thing originally.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was an amazing course on black independent and experimental film! Professor Forster structured the lectures carefully and we had a great balance of student presentations, discussions about the film, dissections of the readings, etc. We watched a large range of films and the readings supplemented the films very well!
Strength: a great array of films to discuss that were all very different and writhing different genres.
I really enjoyed the class, but it would've been great if we had more time for presentations and class activities.

Despite the depth of its syllabus, the course never dives deeply into any piece of mediareadings or films. Many students would not complete the readings and give superficial responses to questions in class. This would make for lackluster discussions that often would not get to the heart of any argument unless the professor intervened. Instead of innovating pathways for students to access hard material, the professor would let the lack of student participation play out. Some of the readings were particularly esoteric, or referential, which wasnt accessible to students not versed in critical theory. To close read and really engage in high-level academia more hand holding is needed to make sure all students are included and interested.

The professor was clearly passionate about the topic and everyone in the class was very engaged. As a result, I looked forward to going to class. The Sunday screenings were the biggest weakness. There was also a lot of readings and short films each week.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the class taught me a lot, and I developed a newfound appreciation for cinema.
Yes, this was one of those courses that forced me to think deeply of what I perceive to be blackness and how it might be helpful to reshape that, especially through media.

I would absolutely recommend the COURSE to another student, if it were taught by a different professor.  I would never recommend a Black friend or peer this course if taught by the current professor, who teaches the course with self righteousness and snobbery.
Yes! It is the professors last class though.
